ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned a little about romantic composers and styles as well as opera in the 1800s. I tuned out pretty much when it got to 1900s and the modern visual art equivalent of music
Basic knowledge of the history of Western art music since 1800

I learned about the history of Western music from 1800 to the present, with particular focus on compositional styles and composers that were characteristic of the evolution of music during this time period. I also learned how to critically listen to, analyze, and write about pieces of Western music with regards to the four key elements of music: pitch, loudness, color, and time.
I learned about the history of musical genres and notable composers starting from 1800, as well as how to do a critical analysis of a musical piece.
Learned about the history of Western art music after Beethoven and musical parameters as it relates to its development

This class was not very effective in teaching me everything it sought out to teach. What I did learn from this class is the basic ways to describe western music using form, melody, harmony, texture, and pitch. I also learned how to listen to a playlist of over 10 hours of music and memorize enough of the songs to identify them in a quiz.

I basically learned the history of Western Art Music from 1800 (Beethoven) to now. I really do feel like I got a great grasp on how music has evolved and changed since then, in many good and bad and weird and interesting ways. This class covers classical music, symphonic music, program music, romantic music, ballet, opera, modernism, impressionism, expressionism, American experimentalism, jazz and its related genres, neoclassicism, serialism, chance music, electronic music, and minimalism. The composers include: Bach, Haydn, Mozart, Beethoven, Schumann, Liszt, Chopin, Berlioz, Brahms, Tchaikovsky, Rossini, Verdi, Wagner, Mahler, Debussy, Schoenberg, Stravinsky, Gershwin, and many many more. If this stuff interests you, take the class for sure. We also covered musical forms and broke down songs from a (simple) theory perspective. The class is very low workload except the midterm, final, and listening exam require a good amount of prep, which is good because it forces you to really learn the stuff.

A very thorough history of classical music in Europe and America, with a focus on who was missing from the conversation  women, composers of color, queer people, etc. Definitely gained skills in listening to music and being able to talk about features in it, even as someone who has played an instrument from a young age.
I learned a lot about musicology and music history since the 19th century and how other historical events affected how music developed
Music history analysis.
I learned about the fundamentals of western art music.
Very good understanding of music 1800s-present. Less emphasis on the present though so Id change the name of the class. I understand the different styles and composers now
Broad arc of Western Art Music history from 1800 to the present. How to listen closely to art music and identify key characteristics.
History of western music, from classical and romantic music, to american music, jazz, and electronic music
History of western art music, how to analyze music, how to write about music.
history of WAM from 1800s to present, listening + identifying different elements in music
An introduction to western music.

In taking this course I learned how to better parse, digest, and understand music. I also gained an incredible amount of knowledge surrounding composers, musical structure and form, various different elements of music, genres, how music was and is affected by historical and geopolitical context, and more.
I learnt a lot about the development of Western art music since Beethoven.
The background and stories of different composers.
None.
Basic critical music listening skills and music history (aka, famous movements/artists and why they are significant) from 1800-2022.
I learned about the progression of western music since 1800.
How to recognize stylistic hallmarks of musical pieces that correspond to different composers or musical periods, and history of composers and musical periods
I learned the history of Western music from the 19th century in relation to the sociopolitical context of Western Europe and the world.
Learned about European/American classical music from 1800 onwards. The class excelled at weaving the history and context with musical analysis.
I developed a broad knowledge of European and American music history, from romantic to minimalist classical music movements, and the political and social climates that shaped those movements.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: This class could have been great. I took this one over Listening to Music because Listening to Music seemed to focus on a lot of weird stuff; I thought this class would focus on classical music from the 1800s. I was terribly wrong. You spend 2ish weeks studying Beethoven, Bach, Shubert, Mendelson, etc but it quickly goes into opera where you stay for several weeks. While I gained a possible appreciation for opera and went to see my first opera due to this class, It was not my intention to academically study opera; if it was, I would have taken an opera class. After 3-4 weeks of exclusively opera, you then pivot to impressionist and modern music (i.e. weird stuff that a layperson wouldn't consider music). A month and a half of this stuff and you realize that while you hoped to learn a lot about the great classical composers so you could have educated discussions about classical music and heighten the enjoyment of famous symphonies, you will instead be beating your head with your headphones as you're forced to listen to atonal noises and train sounds. Some more notes. After 4 years at Yale, this is the only class I've been in that takes lecture attendance, yes, you will be treated like a middle schooler and forced to sign the sign-in sheet at every class, causing a stir as half the class shows up late. It's also published as great for non-musicians, accepting to all, but while that may be what you think, it entirely depends on your TA grading your work. My section TA was great and made me feel (as a musical outsider) welcome, but the TA grading my work was extremely harsh and nitpicky, critiquing my use of words that weren't even musical terms and basically telling me my subjective opinion of music was wrong. Don't take this class for a grade (or at all) because guess what...at the end there is a listening quiz where you have to learn 90+ pieces, the year composed, the composer, and attributes about them (The 90+ include the crappy atonal stuff and train sounds). Overall, if you are like me, hoping to take a fun class outside a stem major and wanting to learn about classical music this is NOT your class.
Prof. Kreuzer is great

I enjoyed that the lectures were very engaging and the sections gave us a good chance to review the topics we weren't familiar with. It would have been interesting to spend a bit more time on modern musical genres like jazz, rock music, or hip hop.

strengths: very organized, low stress, interesting lectures
weaknesses: not really a negative but music experience/knowledge is definitely helpful!

The strengths of this course lie in the course material. The material of this course is extremely interesting if taught appropriately. Unfortunately, the weaknesses of this course come from the course format, instruction, and instructors. The course is in lecture style format but requires participation, which is unusual in and of itself. In addition, the instructor decides to cold-call students in lecture, which is rather daunting considering the material is advertised as not necessitating any prior experience and the fact that there is a massive range of musical knowledge within the students of the class. It was also very evident that students began to avoid sitting in the front during lecture, opting instead to sit in the very back where it was hard to hear, just to avoid the cold calls of the professor. In the sections of the course, the TAs were highly knowledgeable of the material, but so much so that their tone was very often condescending and their teaching style was unhelpful.

Strengths: Manageable workload and fun assignments, interesting lectures, teaches you what it promises to teach you. 
Weaknesses: Definitely helps to have some basic music theory knowledge or just basic music experience to understand some stuff when she breaks down songs. Not necessary, but helps.

I enjoyed the pieces played at the beginning of each class, and always was excited to see how it fit in the story of the day. The biographical information was really interesting in how it influenced the pieces! Professor Kreuzer was really interesting to listen to each class, and section was helpful but nice that you didnt have to go to every week if it was a hectic time of year.

I think the scope of the course is really large and I felt like it was difficult to be able to tell what things I was going to be tested on later because there was so much information, but that might just be the nature of history classes. Everything else was great
Great overview.

I thought in terms of a timeline and topics covered, I thought that this course did a pretty good job of covering a little bit of everything. However, sometimes I feel like certain topics were a bit rushed.

Strengths:
I like what I learned 
Weaknesses
Less people. Focus on the biggest ones. It was too much material and a harder class than it should have been. People want to take this class for fun and for the love of learning
Too strict on attending class/being allowed to watch lecture from home

Strengths: Very interesting material that spanned a wide variety of topics
Weaknesses: Very much a survey into major topics of western music history, so if you're looking for a more in-depth class, this probably won't be a great fit

Strengths: Prof. Kreuzer is incredibly organized, and the TAs were super helpful

Weaknesses: Sometimes the lectures felt long
engaging lectures, fair + well-structured assignments and assessments, interesting material. not quite chronological which was confusing at times but overall helped with understanding course themes

One of the worst courses Ive ever taken at Yale. Professor Kreuzer is less interested in getting the best out of her students or providing them with a healthy environment to learn than playing one big game of gotcha. This course was billed as one that no prior music experience was required for, yet each and every exam or written was highly technical and required extensive knowledge of music theory, far more than what one could expect to learn in 10 short weeks. I would never recommend this course, or any course taught by Professor Kreuzer, to any friends in the future.
Its really a history of classical music. Not a lot of emphasis on other genres.

The interactive lecture format of the course paired with a weekly section was a strength of the course. There is an incredible amount of content and section was helpful to hone in on the most important information and to rehearse information that may have been forgotten since lecture. The lectures being 75-minutes, though necessary for the amount of content covered, made it difficult at times to remain engaged as lectures include both a high volume of content and a longer duration.
It can be more interactive. It was very informative.
Everything is perfect!

Strengths: Good survey of music history, especially for someone like me who plays a bit of saxophone but couldnt (previously) distinguish Schumann from Chopin. Listening exercises force you to think about what youre hearing. 
Weaknesses: After jazz unit, I feel that we should have listened to pop/rock  even the textbook included it, but we just focused on chance/minimalism/process music.
One random thing that could be improved: we got a word bank at the beginning of the semester with words like timbre and meter  would have been super cool/helpful to have a more comprehensive word bank of ~examples~ of those things. Would have been helpful for listening early in the course.

The content was not organized in a way that was conducive to engaged learning, especially for people who do not have a musical background. The instructor assumed a relatively high bar of understanding after explicitly stating that the course was for complete beginners. After asking for feedback on assignments that didn't receive a desired grade, there was very little specificity and no clear direction for improvement.
I don't recall any specific strengths or weaknesses, it was just a good class overall
It was a fun class! The class was pretty big but the TAs managed to keep the level of engagement high. I liked going to lecturesvery concise and to the point!

Strengths: first half of the course! The class was well-designed explaining the histories/contexts of a wide variety of important composers.
Weaknesses: after the midterm, the content felt somewhat obscure and slightly less relevant to the big picture of music history. The course spends a puzzling amount of time on experimental/abstract serialist music while largely neglecting important developments in western music such as film scoring, the evolution of jazz, and early rock music.

The strengths of this course were that if you were already somewhat knowledgeable about classical music, you could get more in-depth info about well-known composers, pieces, and trends, in addition to learning lots of new works. One weakness is that it felt as though to do well, you needed to just regurgitate information rather than critically consider it.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: NO! Unless you want to spend the majority of the semester learning opera and weird modern (1900s) music that's was designed to be unlistenable and offputting stay away!
Yes, I definitely would recommend this course to another student who is interested in music and wants to learn more about how it has developed over time.

I would certainly recommend this course to anyone who is not particularly familiar with the traditions of western art music and would like to gain a greater appreciation for actively listening to music.

if youre interested about music and its history- yes! this class is a brief overview of trends from the 1800s and is relatively low stress. as long as you pay attention in class you will get a lot out of it.

If it was with a different instructor, I would recommend this course to another student. The instructor made the course almost unbearable and illustrated very little interest in actually facilitating learning for students rather than just checking the boxes of the course syllabus.
Absolutely, if they're interested in the topic and want a low workload fun class, this is perfect for that.
yes!! lots of fun and especially easy if you're already familiar with western classical music
Yes, really chill but can learn a lot! Fun to talk about after class. Prof. Kreuzer is one of the better lecturers Ive had at Yale (although I am a STEM student).
Yes, it was fun to go to a lecture and enjoy music and not have to worry about taking so many notes. Good class to credit/d
Yes. Fun class.
I would recommend this course to students genuinely interested in music history, but not for someone who is just trying to find a gut.
Yes, but only if you already know youre interested in the content.
Yes, if you're interested in music history and how social, political events have shaped the development of western music
Yes! So much fun, and you get to listen to a bunch of cool music.
If you are interested in the history of classical music, take this course! Light workload and engaging lectures.

Yes! If you're somone who has a classical music background and doesn't have too much knowledge of WAM history, this course will be super chill but still very engaging. If you don't have that background, the course will still be chill + very engaging, but you might have to put in more effort on listening assignments and such
Absolutely not see above.
Not really. Its not really a gut if thats what youre looking for.
Yes! Prof Kreuzer is great and the class was really interesting!

Yes, I would recommend this course to another studentwith an asterisk. I expected this course to be a fun, easier course, and students are expected to engage somewhat highly, recall a significant amount of content for exams including many different composers, pieces, historical events, and genres of music, and at the end of the semester, to take a listening quiz where they need to blindly recognize eight pieces of music from 1800 to the present. The content is extremely interesting and engaging, but needless to say, it is not an easy course! The workload is less than other courses I've taken, but the rigor is definitely the same.
Yes, if you have interest in classical Western music, you should take it.
Yes! This class is so beautiful!
Absolutely not. Worst class I have taken at Yale.

Yes, I would recommend this course to a student with little background in music history. I found myself loving some units and being utterly disengaged with other lectures, but it was definitely worth it to discover Mussorgsky, Joplin, and a few others. Moreover, the listening gave me the musical skills to articulate certain elements of a composition, which is something I couldnt do before.

I would not. The course material is organized poorly to facilitate connection with and deeper understanding of the material. The instructor and TA's were difficult to work with, and the other students were also frustrated.
Yes, it was very interesting to learn about how classical music has evolved over the past couple centuries. Prior musical knowledge is helpful but not a whole lot is necessary
Yes to any classical music lover, this class gives a great introduction to the history of Western music and introduces great pieces.
Absolutely! If you are interested in classical music this is such an amazing overview course.
